original: A war has been raging for billions of years, killing trillions every single day, while we don't even notice. The war is fought by the single deadliest entity on our planet, the bacteria-fage, or phage for short. A phage is a virus, not quite alive, not quite dead. Also, they look as if someone made them up. Their head is an icosahedron, a sort of dice with 20 faces and 30 edges. It contains the genetic material of the virus, and often sits on a long tail that has led like fibres. There are more fages on earth than every other organism combined, including bacteria. And they are probably everywhere living things exist. Billions are on your hands, in your intestines, and your eyelids right now. Which might make you nervous since fages are responsible for the majority of deaths on earth. But you're lucky. While they do commit genocide for breakfast, they only kill bacteria. Up to 40% of all bacteria in the oceans are killed by them every single day. But fages also have major flaws, like any other virus, fages need a host to survive and we could use. They're not much more than genetic material in a hole, and they specialize. Usually, a phage has chosen one specific bacteria, and maybe some of its very close relatives. These are its prey. Imagine a phage as like a cruise missile that only hunts and kills members of one very unlucky family. When a phage finds its victim, it connects its tail fibers with receptors and uses a sort of syringe to puncture surface. In a weird motion, the phage squeezes its tail and injects its genetic information. Within minutes, the bacteria is taken over. It's now forced to manufacture all the parts of new fages. They only stop when the bacteria is filled up with brand new fages. In the final step, they produce an endolyson, a powerful enzyme that punches a hole in the bacteria. The pressure is so high that the bacteria sort of vomit out all of its incites and dies. New fages are released and begin the cycle of new. In the last few years, bacteria fages have enjoyed the attention of the second devdius beings on earth, humans. Recently, we've started looking into injecting millions of them into our bodies, because we're sort of getting desperate. We screwed up. In the past, a single cart or a sip from the wrong puddle could kill you. The bacteria were our fages, tiny monsters that hunted us mercilessly. But then, about 100 years ago, we found a solution in nature. By accident, we found fungi that produced a compound that killed bacteria antibiotics. Suddenly, we had a powerful superweapon. Antibiotics were set effective that we stopped thinking of bacteria as monsters. Only the old and weakest among us were killed by them. We used antibiotics more and more for less and less serious causes. We lost respect for the monsters and the weapon. But bacteria are living things that evolve, and one by one, they started to become immune against our evidence. This continued until we had created what are called superbox. Bacteria immune to almost everything we have. This immunity is spreading across the world as we speak. By 2050, superbox could kill more humans a year than cancer. The days when a cart or bladder infection or a cough could kill you or your loved ones are coming back. In the US alone, more than 23,000 people die from resistant bacteria each year. But it turns out that fages, our tiny killer virus robots, could save us. We could inject them into our bodies to help cure infections. Hold on, how can injecting millions of viruses into an infection be a good idea? Fages are very, very specialized killers of bacteria. So specialized in fact, that humans are completely immune to them. We are too different. We encounter billions of fages every day and we just pollide the ignore each other. Antibiotics are like carpet bombing, killing everything even the good bacteria in our intestines that we don't want to harm. Fages are like guided missiles that only attack what they're supposed to. Wait a minute, if we use fages to kill bacteria, we're bacteria developed ways of defending themselves. Well, it's more complex than that. Fages evolve too. There has been an arms race between their man bacteria for billions of years and so far, they're doing great. This makes fages smart weapons that are constantly getting better at killing. But even if bacteria were to become immune against our fage, we still might be able to win. It turns out that in order to become resistant to even just a few species of fages, bacteria have to give up their resistance to antibiotics. We might be able to trap them in a catch 22. This has already been successfully tested with a patient who had no other hope left. The bacteria suit a bonus origenosa, one of the most feared bacteria, infected the man's chest cavity. They are naturally resistant to most antibiotics and can even survive in alcoholic hand gel. After years of suffering, a few thousand fages were directly inserted into his chest cavity together with antibiotics the bacteria were immune to. After a few weeks, the infections had completely disappeared. Unfortunately, this treatment is still experimental, and far more companies are still reluctant to invest the necessary billions in a treatment that has no official approval yet. But things are finally changing. In 2016, the largest fage clinical trial to date began and fages are getting more and more attention. And we better get used to it because the era in which antibiotics have been our superweapon is drawing to a close. It might be a weird concept, but injecting the deadliest being on paniturth directly into our bodies could save millions of lives.
